content.description: Jam and undercling the overlap to a difficult move getting on the steep face above.
content.protection: Small-medium cams, 3 bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the second route from the left.

content.description: Start outside of the cave doing a difficult boulder problem that isn’t over until you clip the second bolt from jugs. Shake out, and climb the sequential face and very shallow, right-facing corner. At the last bolt, either finish straight up on thin edges (technical and hard) or do a powerful move out right to a flake and up to a good hold to clip the anchors.
content.location:
200 feet right of “

Bourbon Trail

,” follow the slabby ledge system, and locate a cave in a small alcove.

content.description: Whiskey Wanderer is a very well-bolted and safe sport climb. Climb up on some mildly crumbly rock with some interesting moves. This will clean up with more ascents.
content.location:
It is 100 yards uphill from "

The Bourbon Legend

" and right next to "

Peanut Butter Whiskey

."

content.description:
Begin in the dihedral of

Maker's Mark

, then as the angle eases off, make a spicy traverse left on the face until you reach a handcrack.
content.protection: A standard rack plus runners for the traverse. There are no bolted anchors.
content.location:
Begin the same as for

Maker's Mark

.

climbs.name: The Whiskey Rocks Recliner
climbs.fa: Steve Damboise, Frederic Bonnard, Bobbi Bensman, Greg Miller; 12/20

content.description: Climb the dike, starting out on big holds that lead to the crux.
content.location: It climbs the large, free standing boulder in the middle of the sloping ledge.

content.description: Stem up a short gully to a ledge and slab your way to the top.
content.protection: Pro to 2”, 4 bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is located on the opposite hillside from "

Shaken Not Stirred

". You will pass this wall if you do the shorter but steeper approach from the West to lower W.R.W. It is roughly 10 minutes from campsite 8 following the tree line.

content.description: Climb an easy finger crack to the first bolt. Stand on an expanding flake, and make crux moves to some protruding features and easier slab to the anchor.
content.location: It is located on a slab in the aspen grove West of the parking area.

climbs.name: Whiskey D***
climbs.fa: Frederic Bonnard, Steve Damboise, Greg Miller, Norman, 11/20

content.description: A hard start leads to easy terrain and a steeper headwall where you will encounter the crux.
content.location:
Just right of “

Whiskey Wins Again

,” this makes for a nice, fully bolted warm-up.

content.description: Climb a left-angling crack, negotiate a sloping bulge, and follow a slab straight up.
content.protection: Pro to 0.5”, 5 bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is located on the opposite hillside from "

Shaken Not Stirred

". You will pass this wall if you do the shorter but steeper approach from the West to lower W.R.W. It is roughly 10 minutes from campsite 8 following the tree line.

content.description: Climb the steep, black corner. This has been attempted but will require some more cleaning. Once it’s cleaned up, this should be a classic stem/layback pitch. It is still awaiting a free lead.
content.location:
It is left of  “

Maker's Mark

.”

content.description:
This beautiful little slab starts by "walking the plank" on a log that allows access. Climb up 3 bolts via nice crystals to a cool summit ledge.

One could also do a bouldery start to the slab not adding much to the grade. This was bolted ground up.
content.location:
Follow a trail right of

Maker's Mark

along the cliff base. You will see the obvious slab up and right.

content.description:
This is a fun top rope wall that offers featured slab climbing with multiple moderate variations.

There was a pre-existing, easily accessible, 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
It ascends the main wall to the right of “

Whiskey Wanderer

,”

etc

.

content.description: Climb the obvious offwidth/chimney.
content.protection: Large cams and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is just right of “

Whiskey Wanderer

”.

content.description: The crux is right off the ground getting to the first bolt. Stem and smear up a water groove. The top of the slab becomes very easy. This was bolted ground up.
content.location:
This is located on a slab another 10 minutes hiking south from

Walk the Plank

in a beautiful setting.

climbs.name: That Thing You Do With Your Tongue

content.description: This is a really fun arete problem! The topout is kinda spooky and can hurt if you fall badly.
content.location:
It is in the pile of boulders near "

Platte Rat

."

content.description:
Weird things happen out in the South Platte....

This is a nice, flaring, handcrack boulder problem!
content.location:
It is North of

Bird Dog

on a hill.

climbs.name: Shaken Not Stirred
climbs.fa: Chuck Fitch and Adam Huxley, Dec. 2018

content.description: Multiple cruxes including balancy, crimpy, mantels and steep jugs make this a fun and varied pitch.
content.location: Climb the middle of a steep, south-facing wall at the head of a protected draw. To find the draw, continue south past the other climbs, or approach from the west (see the photo).

content.description: Balance up some steep climbing that leads to an overlap (2 or 3” cam), and follow the slab straight up.
content.protection: 2/3” cam, 5 bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is located on the opposite hillside from "

Shaken Not Stirred

". You will pass this wall if you do the shorter but steeper approach from the West to lower W.R.W. This is roughly 10 minutes from campsite 8 following the tree line.

content.description: This climbs a really sweet rail to nowhere. There is a low start that hasn't been done and will be around V10?
content.location:
It is in a cave between

Bird Dog

and the main wall.

climbs.name: Peanut Butter Whiskey
climbs.fa: Marly Saunders, belayed by Autumn Priestley, equipped by Dave Vuono

content.description: A thin less-than-fingertips start leads to some finger locks and gradually widens to the top. The rock on this one is less than ideal, but it will clean up with more ascents and some lovin'.
content.location:
It is 100 yards uphill from "

The Bourbon Legend

."

content.description: This thing is pretty sweet and packs a punch! Climb up the chimney clipping bolts as it pinches down into an offwidth crux.
content.protection: #4-6 C4 and quickdraws for the chimney. This was bolted by Greg Miller.
content.location:
It is on the main wall, left of

Fireball

.

content.description: Good ol' Maker's... this route ascends a sweet dihedral with a crux in the first 10 or so feet.
content.protection: A standard rack up to a 5. The anchor bolts up top were placed by Greg Miller.
content.location:
It is located to the right of

Fireball

.

climbs.name: Irish Cream
climbs.fa: Mike Sheridan, Regina Kearney, Quintin Sheridan

content.description:
Irish Cream is an excellent beginner trad route. It begins with easy climbing wide at the start then hands to thin hands.

There is a two bolt anchor rap from the top. It is not a good route to TR. There are nice views on top.
content.location: On the tallest boulder near the aspen grove, it climbs a low angle crack on the southwest side. The crack is to the right of the dead tree with baby bear claw marks.

content.description: Begin with a stand up move off a horizontal, and crimp along a dike eventually encountering a mantel. Follow an easier slab to the top.
content.location: It is located on a slab in the aspen grove West of the parking area.

content.description:
This ascends a gently overhanging handcrack with some thin hands thrown in.

Rappel or lower off the bolts for the ??.
content.protection: #1 Camalots to #3.5 Camalots. Belay on ledge above with #0.75 Camalots, or use the bolts on the ??.
content.location: It is right of ??.

content.description:
Stem off a boulder, and layback and undercling the corner. A bouldery crux at the end leads to a thin slab.

This was named in honor of our friend Bob Dergay who passed away May 2019.
content.protection: Pro to 2”, 2 bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the leftmost route on the wall.

content.description: Figure out how to get off the ground and reach a jug. A couple more unprotected moves to a red dike and you’ll reach the crack and gear. Follow it to the top.
content.protection: Pro to 1” and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: It is on the far right side of the TR wall.

content.description: Levitate up any holds that work best for you and then climb up an easier right-facing corner.
content.location:
It is the first route you come to once entering the small corridor roughly 15 feet left of the “

Dergaynator

”.

content.description:
Clip the first bolt off the top of a pointed boulder, make a committing step across utilizing a sloping hold out

left

and an awkward mantel, and

follow

the beautiful slab to the top. This was led/bolted ground up.
content.location: It is on the left side of crag on the face of a large chimney.

content.description: A difficult start and compression moves lead up the seam to good face holds.
content.protection: Small cams, 3 bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the rightmost route.

climbs.name: The Bourbon Legend
climbs.fa: Danny Parker, Ashley Cracroft, Tyler Dziedzina

content.description:
The whiskey version of an urban legend....

It is maybe one of the best crack boulder problems in North America and certainly the best I know of in Colorado! This goes through every size you can think of from offwidth down to tips. Start all the way back in the cave, and invert into the offwidth from the ground. Work your way out by doing some surprisingly difficult inverted shuffling, doing a pivot, then gaining powerful fists through the first roof, then move on to hands/thin hands through the second roof gaining the vertical finger crack, and top out on a solid jug on the right, avoiding the kitty litter. It is sustained all the way.
content.protection: Pads and spotters, a fall from the top would suck
content.location:
It is a bit of a hike past the main wall near the end of the hill. You will pass an aspen grove in the main gully, and it's about 200-300 yards further from that.

The coordinates are: 39.210561°, -105.333878°.

content.description: Climb a positive layback to a tricky traverse before heading straight up on harder climbing. This has been attempted but may require some cleaning down low.
content.location:
It is left of “

The Whiskey Rocks Recliner

” on the main wall.

content.description: This climbs a right-angling finger crack traverse. Start up a water streak into a dirty crack. Once you are past the flake, the protection and climbing gets significantly better. It is fun to lead and shitty to clean. Would get more stars if it weren't for the first 15 feet.
content.location: It is on the hiker's trail in.

content.description:
If you are short, getting off the ground might be the crux. Start by grabbing a jug and figuring out how to get your feet on it. Follow the steep water groove to an overlap and easy slab to the top. This shares the same anchor as "

Whiskey for Men

".
content.location: Located on slab in the aspen grove West of the parking area.

content.description: Climb up a shallow, right-facing corner to a short crack. Good holds lead to two back-to-back mantels, and slab to the anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts, medium cams, and a 2 bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Astroglide
climbs.fa: Wendy Lindberg belayed by Greg Miller, 5/18

content.description: This route can be done via the chimney (5.6) or starting in the obvious, left-angling crack to the right (5.8). Unless you are extremely thin, you will probably not fit through the hole at the top of the chimney. There is also a direct variation climbing out the A frame formed by the chimney (5.10-).
content.protection: Pro to 3” and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Begin in the obvious chimney on the left side of the crag.
